Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Polish tailor. He shows the label.

Speaker: bohdan
Dialogue: For the bread.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Come here. SMITH returns the stare, then slowly approaches.

Speaker: andrei
Dialogue: Take the coat.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: I want the sweater. ANDREI doesn't move.

Speaker: andrei
Dialogue: You have no authority, here. VALKA gets up, moves slowly to ANDREI, a smile on his lips. Then he casually reaches down as if to tuck his trousers deeper into his boots, reaches for something, and in one slow balletic movement, swings up and stretches out his hand to ANDREI, and ANDREI sobs and leans to one side.

Speaker: bohdan
Dialogue: Was that really necessary? In the dim light ANDREI's face is grey as he sags to the floor. None of the other prisoners move to help him, nor do they show any sign of concern, as VALKA places the knife back in his boot and returns to the game. YURI steps forward and strips the sweater from the dead man, handing it on to VALKA, who passes it to BOHDAN. BOHDAN examines it professionally, wipes a little blood off his hands.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Here he is. He reaches out to touch a human toe poking out of the rocks. As they work - Close on the face of ANDREI, as they continue to uncover his body.

Speaker: lazar
Dialogue: Damn! Picked clean! Bloody thieves.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Keep your voice down, be grateful there's anything left. They reach into the grave to retrieve the underwear.

Speaker: commandant
Dialogue: Enemies of the People! Look about you...and understand... it is not our guns, or our dogs, or our wire, that forms your prison. Siberia is your prison. All four million square miles of it. Here in Camp 105, you will work hard. Work and you eat. Eat and you live. Close on JANUSZ and his friends.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I'm an old man. But I'll be alive in the morning. He won't. He goes to move away, hesitates, turns back to JANUSZ.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: American? He looks back to SMITH walking away toward the barracks.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Stalin doesn't like foreigners. That includes Poles. You are Polish aren't you? JANUSZ still staring after SMITH.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Yes, I am.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: I love you Poles, your burning sense of injustice, your yearning for freedom. .

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Weiszczek, Janusz.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: And your 'prayer', may I ask?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: That's what they told me.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Ten years?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Twenty. KHABAROV indicates himself.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: 58.14. Sabotage, ten years. They begin walking toward the distant barrack buildings.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Oh there's that Polish spirit! I observe things - your demeanor, your, may I say, certain 'swagger'. 'Cavalryman', that's how I'd cast you. He leans forward, whispers.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: How could we know Russia would stab us in the back?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: And you were on the Soviet side of the line, and they arrest you, and thousands like you. Accuse you of spying-And they torture you? You signed a 'confession'?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I wouldn't sign, so they tortured someone else.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Usual tactics - they torture a close friend who names you as a spy - a neighbor? Your old school teacher? A friend?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: It was claimed I was elevating the status of the old nobility.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You got ten years for a performance in a film?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: I've had better notices. And they enter their hut.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: The 'Urki'.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Who are they?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Professional criminals, your ordinary run of the mill murderers and thieves, don't stare at them. The guards let them run things in here. They are to be feared.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Why would they let them 'run things'?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: They are considered the by-product of bourgeoisie society and therefore 'Friends of the People'. We political prisoners are 'Enemies of the People'. Russia has become one vast prison - slave labor. You see even this camp is expanding to take in another thousand prisoners. JANUSZ looks over to a group of Asiatic prisoners.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: And do any ever wriggle out of the net? KHABAROV considers a moment, then leads him away from the surrounding prisoners. He lowers his voice to a whisper.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: You should be more careful. Stalin has eyes and ears everywhere, even in here. He leans closer to JANUSZ.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: And how long have you been here?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Eleven months and twenty-nine days. KHABAROV offers his hand.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Cut last year and never collected! Quickly hide them inside your fresh cut timber! BOHDAN moving closer. It becomes a race to transport all the old logs to their pile and to conceal them inside the fresh cut logs.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: He knows. KHABAROV shrugs.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: He knows, but he doesn't care, as long as his arse is protected. This is 'Tufta'. Bull-shit. JANUSZ nods his thanks.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: You want me to make a sketch of you?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: No. Not me. TOMASZ puzzled.

Speaker: bohdan
Dialogue: Keep going and you'll get some bread - so how does this 'Long John Silver' find the treasure?

Speaker: yuri
Dialogue: I knew a type like that. Remember Igor? He had one leg.

Speaker: bohdan
Dialogue: Shut up.  Go on. The story resumes, ZORAN giving it all he's got, when VALKA appears a sketch in his hand. He passes it to BOHDAN. CLOSE on the sketch - a lusty naked woman. VALKA makes a gesture implying masturbation. BOHDAN examines the drawing before licking the back of it, lifting his shirt, sticking it to his chest, then lowering his shirt again. He waves VALKA away.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: For the lice I have an old folk remedy.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: The mines. They blast at night. He pauses to let JANUSZ catch up, then looking furtively about him, he crouches by a drift of snow.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We're going to leave them here overnight? Why?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: You'll see. JANUSZ stares up at the wire, then to a distant watchtower, its searchlight briefly illuminating him. KHABAROV follows his eye-line.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: We believe about 500 kilometers north of Lake Baikal.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We could follow the edge of the Lake, it runs due South.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Why wait?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: It's 1000 kilometers to the border, maybe more. We need careful planning, stock-pile food. I've already begun - trading, dealing. You could do the same. In the Autumn the weather is predictable. We need the early snows to cover our tracks. JANUSZ nods.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What about my friends?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: If you trust them. But they won't all survive.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: But they'd die free men. KHABAROV offers his hand, and they shake.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Temperature is dropping. Below 60 they're not supposed to send us out. Know how to tell the temperature? You see frosty fog - it's 40 below. If you exhale easily but in a rasping fashion? 50 below. When your spit freezes? More than 60 below. He hoiks and spits. Close on the ball of spit mid-air. Freeze-frame. It's a solid glittering crystal of ice.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We need to make shelter.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We'll freeze to death in less than an hour.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Yes, but lose 200 men and you'll have some forms to fill out. Could go badly for you. The GUARD dimly considers this. The prisoners begin to stir, some shouting out that they should turn back. The GUARD alarmed, orders the prisoners to the ground - other guards level their rifles as the mass of men lay down on the freezing ground. All but SMITH.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: You are brave man - Dragan Zoran, Yugoslav this is Janusz Wieszczek the youngster is Kazik, both Polish.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Andrejs Voss, Latvian.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: English our common language! SMITH nods.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: And you're ?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Smith.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Your first name?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Mister.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Mister Smith?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: That's right. As the blizzard grows in intensity, JANUSZ reaches into his pocket for strips of pine-bark collected earlier. He hands them out to his companions. They watch as he chews on the bark. The others follow his example. Watching from a short distance away is GUARD NO. 1. He takes note of the group as future troublemakers.

Speaker: kazik
Dialogue: English, yes. They share a smile.

Speaker: prof
Dialogue: I was only saying, these collars - the same used by ancient Egyptian people.

Speaker: kazik
Dialogue: Yes, but on their horses probably.

Speaker: prof
Dialogue: No. Same. On people.

Speaker: kazik
Dialogue: How do you know that?

Speaker: prof
Dialogue: I was professor of Egyptology. Leningrad University. KAZIK manages a look at his companion, before putting even more effort into dragging the load.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Are you crazy? They'll shoot you.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Got to get out! SMITH stares at him. He's delirious and begins to shake with cold. SMITH grabs his shoulder and drags him back to where the POINT'-MAN works, thrusting JANUSZ's hands around the pipe. The POINT-MAN waves them away but SMITH bribes him with a slice of bread. SMITH turns back to JANUSZ - the warmth of the pipe beginning to have its effect.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What can be done?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: He knows a way through the wire. SMITH slaps a hand over his mouth, glancing at the Point- Man, before dragging JANUSZ further away.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: His name is Khabarov. Now SMITH understands.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: The actor.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You know him?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He has no intention of escaping.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He's aliar. Been here foryears -seeksout new arrivals, mewhen Ifirstcame here. He justlikes totalkabout escape. I'veknown others like him.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Why should I believe you?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Nothing is for nothing in the camps. From you he gets your energy, your spirit. You feed his 'dream' of escape. You help keep him alive. He's no more than a leech.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You're a cold bastard, Mister.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I thought you were a loner?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Can't be done alone. Besides you have a weakness that could be useful to me.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: And what's that?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Compassion. If anything happens to me, I'm counting on you carrying me. JANUSZ knows he's not joking.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Tonight. KHABAROV looks from the footprints to JANUSZ, a horrified look on his face.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: It's a passing storm!

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It'll do, it'll cover our tracks.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: Impossible! We need preparation, detailed plans, maps

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: But the distances! And food! What about food?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We've been trading, the American is with us. He has food, you have food.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: How long will that last?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I've spent half my life in the woods and mountains. We'll live off the land.

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: It can't be done! JANUSZ shocked at the change in his friends' demeanor, the appalling realization that SMITH was right about him. He seizes his arm.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: How do we get through the wire?

Speaker: khabarov
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Your friend, Lazar, he knows doesn't he? A look of fear crosses KHABAROV's face. Someone behind JANUSZ. JANUSZ turns. VALKA, a few paces away watching them. KHABAROV scuttles back inside the barracks. JANUSZ hesitates a moment, then follows.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: You can't see, can you? A look of panic crosses the boy's face.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: There are no secrets here.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: The game goes against me. Small debt - lose fingers. Big debt, they take head. Me, big debt. But one thing I never gamble is my Wolf. He removes the knife from JANUSZ's throat, tilts the blade to show a wolf's head incised into the blade.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Get up. Or we die right now. You know how fast dogs travel. He turns to the others.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Knife . VALKA has never taken an order from a 'Political' in his short life.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Your knife. With a glance to the others he reluctantly draws his knife from his boot and passes it to JANUSZ. While the group furiously dig, JANUSZ collects and trims fallen timber. As the hole deepens, JANUSZ begins to make a trellis roof. The voices change direction. They go still. Are they surrounded? They resume their digging with greater intensity, the hole now more than a meter at its deepest, JANUSZ placing the branches to cover their hide.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We've got to make fire!

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: No! You saw how close they were! KAZIK sinks to the snow, then ZORAN.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We die either way, might as well die warm.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Once upon a time, in the days of wooden ships, there was a great storm in far away seas. A merchant ship hurried toward big rocks, lightening in the sky, the waves as high as house-tops. Very, very cold, brrr! The ship smashed onto the rocks, the sailors cried in fear, called out to God, but they all drowned. All but one, Mr. Robinson Crusoe. He woke to find himself all alone on a desert island. For many years he lived without any human companions, until one day he saw something shocking! What was it? A human footprint. He was no longer alone. But was the stranger friend or foe? Another ship wrecked sailor? Or, a cannibal? All turn as a flicker of flame begins at the base of the kindling. While JANUSZ blows at the flame, MR. SMITH feeds in small shavings. The group watch with the awe and wonder usually reserved for child-birth. Then everyone is making a contribution - adding a few leaves, or tiny twigs, like offerings, as the fire grows and spreads.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: You stare at me like the snake at the rabbit or is it the other way 'round? VALKA turns to the others with a silver-toothed smile, indicates SMITH.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Snow, falling from trees. They relax a little.

Speaker: kazik
Dialogue: When can we travel by day?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: When I say.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: How far have we come?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Twenty, thirty kilometers.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Is that all?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Less, if we've been going in circles, like the chicken without its head.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: He reads the trees, don't you?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Something like that. He spreads out a piece of cloth on the snow at his feet.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We share. JANUSZ reaches out for the sack of food. VALKA glances at the others, then passes it to him. TOMASZ has already begun to organize seven slices of bread laying one of VOSS's fish heads on each. one. He hands them out. They eat in silence, savoring every bite. ZORAN removes the fish-head, passing it back to TOMASZ. Then he places a thin layer of snow on the bread like a canape. He eats daintily, his little finger extended like a dowager at a tea party, raising a smile from his exhausted companions.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You've made a bargain with the Devil.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: For direction he looks at grass and mosses, what's that? I swear to God he better know what he's doing.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You should be grateful you're here at all.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Gratitude is for dogs. He moves away from SMITH, his eyes fixed on JANUSZ, who is again studying moss on the side of a tree.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Wolves it's only wolves.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: 'Only wolves', great.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: South! To Lake Baikal! Cheers from the watching group.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: You are the 'Pakhan'.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What's 'Pakhan'?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Boss of criminals.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We're not criminals, we're escaping from criminals.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: I swear to God you win my respect with your sticks and pine-cones. I'll stand between you and death.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You want to be my bodyguard?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: It's the Urka way. You have me and you have the Wolf. He touches the knife in its bark sheath at his belt. JANUSZ increases the pace, VALKA pushing himself to keep up with his 'Pakhan'.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: To Mongolia? No. I go further. To America. The first SMITH has heard of this. TOMASZ turns from examining their store of food.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: We need meat.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: I can make traps.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We'll be moving too fast to wait for traps.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: We find farms, villages, get food there.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: There's a bounty on our heads.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: We steal it. At night. They never know.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: We're not thieves.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Barbed-wire. ZORAN puzzled, but TOMASZ gets it.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: He's making a fish-hook. JANUSZ smiles at SMITH's ingenuity.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It's how we'll survive isn't it, Mister?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Fish? I don't eat fish.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Then you'll die. KAZIK has a far-away look in his sight-less eyes. He speaks in Polish to JANUSZ.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: What does he say?

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: He asked Janusz if he believes in God's forgiveness. This has come from seemingly nowhere.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Save your philosophy. Concentrate on keeping up with us instead. He gets up and goes in search of more wood, the others surprised at his cold tone. The rest of the group also begin to prepare their camp. Most gather wood while TOMASZ, the 'quartermaster', makes their meal, and JANUSZ the fire. VOSS keeps an eye on KAZIK who, demonstrating his independence while it's still light, and his desire to contribute, returns with a load of wood, turning back into the forest for more. Others gather wood, and as the light fades, begin to take up positions by the growing fire, roll cigarettes, etc. VOSS looks anxiously for KAZIK. He has not returned.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: He has night-blindness.

Speaker: kazik
Dialogue: I thought I was alone!

Speaker: kazik
Dialogue: I'll just sit for a minute. The PROF. sits beside him.

Speaker: kazik
Dialogue: We made it. We really made it. Isn't that something.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: A free man died here today. Amens are muttered. The group remain by the grave reluctant to leave. All but VALKA who looks about restlessly.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Young always die first. The others look at him.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I made a mistake.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: They'll find our bones and your drawings a hundred years from now, and say - 'a fine example of Early Gulag Man'.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Shut up with your jokes! Go and find food like the others.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: You do the shutting up! Drawing like you're on holiday. I'm sick.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: I cook. They find food. What do you ever do? Nothing!

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I make them laugh.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Not any more. ZORAN turns away from him, curling up into a foetal position.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: What do you have? Come on, no holding back. SMITH approaches from the cave, hands over two small fish, his day's catch. VOSS steps forward with a dead squirrel. VALKA has nothing. TOMASZ reaches for their cooking pot cooling by the fire. He passes a cup to

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Who will be first? JANUSZ looks at him.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You mean the first to die? VALKA nods, indicates TOMASZ.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: I think that sucker, the artist. But better if it was him. He nods toward ZORAN.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It might be you. VALKA shrugs.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: More soft. More tender. JANUSZ shakes his head, 'no'.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We'll get food when we get to Lake Baikal, plenty of fish there.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: You said we should have seen Lake a week ago. We're lost, Pakhan. JANUSZ stares into the fire as VALKA lays down to sleep.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I'll be back in a week - if I find the lake. If not, you're on your own.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: I come too.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I'll travel faster alone. Mr. Smith will be the Pakhan while I'm gone. JANUSZ turns and with a nod of the head 'follow me', to SMITH, he moves off.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I know. Valka.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Don't let him out of your sight.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Good luck. As JANUSZ heads off into the forest.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Three days from here. South by West. He collapses. VOSS shouts for the fire to be built up, hot water to be boiled. He feels his pulse, checks his eyes.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Stones! Gather stones! Heat them in the fire!

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What's the 'brick'?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What did I say?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Something about a loose brick. JANUSZ nods, offers no explanation.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I expect nothing less.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: So you better get better quick if you want to see home again.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We could've used you in the Polish army. Fired you out of a cannon. He closes his eyes, lapses back into a deep sleep.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: I swear to God, those mother- fuckers would cut off our heads, take them to secret police. Get more for us than they would for their fish. JANUSZ, impatient to move on, is already on his feet. ZORAN rolls onto his back with a groan.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We're being followed.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Followed? Where?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Fifty yards back. A man on his own. May have seen us - crossed into the trees beside the track. A silence as they consider their options. VALKA draws his knife.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: No killing.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He gives us away, the soldiers will be on us in no time.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Valka, go back on the other side of the track, then come up behind, in case he makes a run for it. VALKA moves off, gliding through the trees on the left of the track. The others wait a beat, then move into the trees on the right side of the track picking up fallen timber as weapons. JANUSZ is in the lead when in a clearing not fifty paces ahead, a figure steps out from behind a tree. JANUSZ stops, holding up a hand for the others to stay where they are. He stares at the small figure - a young woman. There's a glimpse of a dirty skirt under her coat, a scarf tied loosely about her neck. Wisps of chestnut hair stray out from under a moth-eaten fur hood. She looks frightened and desperate.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What? What is it?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: She's Polish. Been following us for several days.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: What does she want?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Food? Protection? She's been too afraid to approach us until she was sure we weren't Russians.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: She wants to travel with us?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: She's on the run, like us. Escaped from a Russian collective farm.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: I swear to God I know this type - street gypsies, there are thousands like that, less use than a dog! JANUSZ looks back to the GIRL who watches them from the clearing.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: She's starving.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We can't feed ourselves.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Zoran?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Maybe it's kinder to leave her.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: She's been sent to us. We can't leave her.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We have no choice. JANUSZ knows this is true.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I'm sorry. He reaches into his bag, passes her a fish and some nuts and berries. It's all she can do to refrain from eating it right away.

Speaker: the girl
Dialogue: Go back. He guesses at what this might mean.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: If we had enough food She stares at him, nods, then walks back toward the path, returning in the direction from which she came.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Her name is, Irena.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Why do we do this?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: So we don't look like thieves and robbers. ZORAN approaches him, blade in hand.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: She's educated. Speaks good English. And French.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: That right.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You don't like her, do you?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Speak to Valka about her. He doesn't even think she's Polish.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I did speak to him. And the others. They agree she comes with us.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: It's decided then?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You disagree.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Apart from food she'll slow us down. There's no room for sentimentality. You know that.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Can you swim?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: Yes, Mister.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You wouldn't lie to me?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: I'm not lying, Comrade. That was a slip of the tongue, and SMITH is made uneasy by it.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: And don't call me, 'comrade'. With a shout the group plunge into the icy water, swimming one-handed, their packs held above water level in the other. It's only when they reach the other side they realize IRENA is still on the opposite bank. The others urge her to swim across. She hesitates a moment then runs upstream to where the river is frozen.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Janusz tells me your family were Kulaks?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: Yes. Just a cow and some pigs.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Were your parents arrested with you?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: They're dead. She swats at a few mosquitos hovering around her face.

Speaker: her tears
Dialogue: They walk in silence a few paces, and she dries with the corner of her sleeve.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You can't swim can you? She looks up at him.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You've never been in the water in your life. She laughs coquettishly.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: But I got across, didn't I?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: And, you said you lived on a farm near Warsaw? IRENA puzzled.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: The Soviets didn't get that far. That was German territory. She nervously swats the mosquitos.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We'll have to go 'round it.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Quicker through it.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: They'll have dogs. Raise the alarm. We wouldn't stand a chance

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: We need food again, Pakhan.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I know we need food, but we're not going into that town, risk everything. SMITH gets up.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We're wasting time. He strikes off up a slope toward the hills behind the town.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Where's Valka?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He was behind Zoran.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I'm not his keeper.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Damn him! He looks back down to the town.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He could turn us in for the bounty.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: And risk arrest?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: He'd bribe his way out of it.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: He might.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: It's an opportunity. We're rid of him.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: We don't need his knife. We can make one from deer bone.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Come on! Let's go!

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: So. SMITH moves swiftly, grabs him by his collar and spins him into the tree.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Could have got us all killed.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: You tear my coat

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Fool! He releases him and VALKA staggers back, reaching down to a bulging sack. He tips out the contents - various foodstuffs including a freshly killed rabbit and a bottle of vodka.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: 'Fool' is it? It's then they notice blood splashed over his trousers.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: You know when they put the children of the political prisoners in the orphanage, they change their names, so later, the parents can never find them.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Is that what happened to you?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: I didn't have parents. But that's what happened to her. He passes IRENA the bottle. She glares back at him.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: They called me 'Rykov', but I remembered our Polish name - 'Zulinski'. I used to say it every night before I went to sleep.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: The story you told us

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: And you ran away. She nods. VALKA grinning proudly at her.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: She lived in the streets, like me! He breaks into one of his Urki songs. IRENA translates.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: It's about a mother complaining to her son that he's a thief, just like his father... it goes on and says, 'but if you are strong enough to fight 'til death - you will conquer fate'. She joins VALKA in the chorus.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: There it is! Again! JANUSZ mystified.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: But what did you say to him?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: That I was an escaped convict who was being plagued by mosquitos. As they round a bend and disappear from sight, TOMASZ's voice drifts back.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: A small stone church in a little village. Very peaceful. I grew up in that village. Then,

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I went on business. Once a year - government clients of course! Then,

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Is that right?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: And Zoran was on business in Moscow, arrested in Red Square, he said he was just taking a photo of the Kremlin! He's an accountant.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Well, I'll be damned. Never knew a funny accountant.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: Don't you talk to each other?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: In the camps you learn to say as little as possible. They walk on in silence, IRENA sneaking a look up at him.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Mr. Smith? An American? Working on the Moscow metro?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Why did he come to Russia for God's sake?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: The Depression. His son came with him.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What happened to his son?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: They shot him. He was seventeen.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: The Mongolian border is on the other side of those tracks. Two ARMED SOLDIERS can be seen walking along the tracks.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Can't we go around this?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: This is the main line. It's going to be like this everywhere.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We don't have a choice.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We cross at night. Their attention is caught by the passing of a long freight train, horn sounding over the bucolic scene.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: What's that you're making?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: A cross for your tombstone.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Valka?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Why do you have arseholes tattooed on your chest? VALKA stops. Stares back.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: You think it's funny? They are great men. ZORAN laughs.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Sure he does. Then he puts both of them in a camp for twenty-five years. VALKA goes back to his carving.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Love it later. We need to get as far from this border as possible. ZORAN faces Russia and as if bowing at the end of a performance.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Thank you Mother Russia for your hospitality! I definitely will not be coming back! It's only then that we notice that VALKA has not crossed through. He stands staring at them from the Soviet side. It's clear he's going no further. JANUSZ crosses back to him, and they talk through the wire.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: They'll catch you if you stay, you know that.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: No, America?

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: It's not for me - 'Freedom'. Wouldn't know what to do with it, I swear to God. He places his hand on the wooden hilt of his knife, sticking out of his waistband.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Good luck, Valka.

Speaker: valka
Dialogue: Good luck, Pakhan. And he turns and walks away. JANUSZ walks toward the distant group and by the time he looks back, VALKA is gone.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: It's here too.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: This changes everything. IRENA looks at the grassy plains all about them.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: Nowhere to hide.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: After China is Tibet. Religious people. Buddhists.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: But isn't Tibet closed to foreigners? I remember reading that.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Their religion would compel them to shelter us. We could go to Lhasa, the capital.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: We break out of one 'closed country' and now we plan to break into another? I like 'open' countries. TOMASZ and JANUSZ exchange a few excited words in Polish. IRENA translates.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: They say we could go beyond Tibet. Over the mountains. To India.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: What mountains?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: The Himalayas.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: We could join the British Army. First fight Nazis then Russians!

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Go over the Himalayas? How? On a magic carpet? A silence as they contemplate the massive distances stretching ahead of them.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: No! Andrejs, no! VOSS tries to free his arm.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Why not? We're hungry!

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You want the locals after us too? They break into Polish, a blazing argument, months of pent up frustration. VOSS picks up the sheep and carries it inside the ruin.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You feel it?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: Feel what?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We're being watched. IRENA uneasy, squints in the direction of the hills. And you can feel it. Like a John Ford western there's a sense of being in Indian territory, of their every move watched by unseen eyes.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: What happened here?

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: The same as happened in Russia. Churches closed, priests shot or taken to camps, religion banned. They came to my church, in Latvia. Destroyed everything, declared it a 'museum'. Later that night, there was a lone guard. A boy.

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: Russki? A glance between SMITH and JANUSZ. Much may hang on his answer.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: No. American. The OLD MAN maybe doesn't get the 'American' part, but he gets that they are not Russian. He seems pleased about that.

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: Lhasa? SMITH nods.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Lhasa. Yes. Tibet. JANUSZ points South.

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: Pilgrim?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: No horses?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We are too poor to have horses. The OLD MAN points at IRENA.

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: Wife? SMITH looks at IRENA.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Daughter. IRENA moves closer to him. SMITH puts a protective arm about her shoulder. The OLD MAN considers the situation for a moment longer before abruptly turning, and followed by his band, galloping off toward the distant hills. Looks between the group, not exactly of relief, as there's a feeling it may not be the last they see of the riders. IRENA looks up at SMITH, smiles at him. Something about him calling her his daughter has touched some hidden place. SMITH, a little embarrassed, smiles back.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: What did you do that for? I was in the middle of this beautiful dream - just about to eat some salt, I could already taste it. I want to go back to that dream.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Then add two sprigs of rosemary and a pinch of nutmeg.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Nutmeg? What about the salt?

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: We'll get to that. Now, add the oil and leave it to marinate, while you prepare the chicken. That's where the salt comes in...

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Rub it into the skin of the chicken with a little of the paprika.

Speaker: z oran
Dialogue: Double the salt.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: I can't just double the salt! It'll be too salty.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I don't care, just do it.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: I'm not going to ruin it.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Janusz! JANUSZ hesitates, looks at VOSS who holds up their water- bag.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What lake? It's a mirage. He plods on, away from the shimmering vision. There's little the others can do but trust JANUSZ, and slowly they follow.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I'm too tired to sleep.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Why not keep walking?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I'm for that, if we can wake Andrejs. They look to where VOSS sleeps.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Yes, but haven't you noticed? He points upward to the low clouds obscuring the stars.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What about water?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I don't see any. I'm trying to remember my school geography but I seem to recall the Gobi Desert somewhere in Southern Mongolia. JANUSZ begins scooping out a hole in the pebbly ground. It's funnel-shaped, narrow at the base. The others watch as he lines the sides with dried deerskin, placing their cooking pot in the base.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: We may pick up a little morning dew. Glad of something practical to do they all set about digging and lining holes with anything to hand.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: You were asleep!

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: No I wasn't.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: You were following the sound of my footsteps - sleep-walking. The others have stopped. ZORAN takes the backpack from VOSS, and places it on the exhausted IRENA.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Janusz? JANUSZ follows him to the rise. SMITH points to his discovery. JANUSZ squints against the light.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It's another mirage. SMITH shakes his head 'no'.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We have no more water. I see trees. Where there's trees there's water.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It's East. We must head South. The others have joined them, staring toward the distant shape.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I've never doubted you, Janusz. Not once. But we must give it a try.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: No. We must keep going South! You'll kill us all!

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Damn it, we're already dying. JANUSZ goes to move on, SMITH grabs his shirt sleeve, a short pathetic struggle sees them fall to their knees, VOSS and TOMASZ move to separate them. SMITH is the first to stand, brushing sand and dirt from his clothes. He turns to the others.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It's a mirage. Just a mirage. SMITH keeps walking away - a strange echo of the incident in Siberia when he walked away from the guards. Perhaps it is this memory that causes the others to turn silently, and collecting their few possessions, to follow him. JANUSZ watches a while, then slowly follows.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Mirages don't have birds! Wider, and they're running, running with the last of their precious energy.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Just a little. Don't fill yourselves. More scoops follow in quick succession, enough to splash hands and faces. VOSS calls from a few yards away.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Fire. Coals are still warm. SMITH and JANUSZ join him, examining the ground about the fire.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Lots of tracks. Nomads?

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Maybe others will come?

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: Over here! The remains of a meal! There's still meat on the bones! He points to the cooked remains of some animal. Using VOSS's deer-bone knife he scrapes meat from the bones, others just attacking any bone they find.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Don't eat it all! He manages to save at least half of the meat, wrapping it in a cloth, and putting it in VOSS's backpack.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: At least we have water here.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: But no food.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Other nomads will come. Water their flocks.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: When? Next week? Next month?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: We could wait a few days, at least.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Without food, we'll only get weaker. Maybe too weak to travel.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: These last days - I don't know that I could go through that again.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: It was a miracle finding this. Can we count on another?

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: I say we stay.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What are you looking at me for? Ask Janusz. He's already made up his mind for us, haven't you, Janusz? JANUSZ says nothing.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: We're in trouble.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I know that, but they mustn't.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: They know.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You can survive a month or more without food, but water?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Days?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Maybe two days, maybe less in this heat.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What about what we're getting from condensation?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It's the only thing keeping us alive. But for how long?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Can you get us back to the waterhole?

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: When we worked the fields, during the hot summers, we used to suck on small stones like these. Don't know why but it made us feel less thirsty. ZORANpicks up a pebble.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: We've eaten just about everything else.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: You don't eat it, just suck on it. At this moment IRENA falls again, her knees buckling and her face pitching into the sand in almost one movement. They turn her over again, wiping the sand from her nose and mouth. SMITH makes a shelter over her with their sticks and jackets. She lies with her eyes closed, her breathing coming in harsh gasps. Both legs are now swollen to the knees. He touches the swelling and the marks his fingers make remain for some seconds.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: I'm becoming a nuisance. She looks down at her legs.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Do they hurt you?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: No, not at all. They must be swelling because I've walked so far. Don't you think, Mister? SMITH nods reassuringly then quickly turns away, a look of deep anguish passing across his face.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Save it for Irena. We've got our pebbles. And he pops one in his mouth, makes out it's delicious and soothing. In the now familiar ritual they scoop out holes in the sand, lining them with their jackets, hopeful of collecting a little moisture overnight.

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: I can walk alright if I can lean a little on you. They each lightly lay a hand on her elbow.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Can you go on?

Speaker: irena
Dialogue: I think so. But what about Mr. Smith? SMITH struggling for breath is back on his feet, waving them on. VOSS and JANUSZ each put an arm about her and half-carrying, half-dragging her, they set off again but it's no use, she's lost all her strength.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: I'm going to carry her.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: I like this one. When did you do that? He holds up a sketch of KAZIK, showing him examining one of his battered shoes.

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: On the train. Poor Kazik, always the trouble with his feet. ZORAN holds up a drawing of himself.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Who's this?

Speaker: tomasz
Dialogue: You. ZORAN looks at it again genuinely shocked.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: My father maybe, but is that how I look now? A chuckle from the others. SMITH stares at a sketch of IRENA.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: You caught her smile. SMITH passes the sketch to JANUSZ as TOMASZ lays back down, a smile on his face. He looks up at the stars. He knows he's dying and has accepted the fact. This in turn has given strength to his friends, and between them all is a feeling of love and a kind of peace.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Do you see it?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Come on, Jan.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: But do you see it?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: No. He helps him to his feet and they continue on.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Eagles live in mountains. SMITH looks at the featureless landscape ahead.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: They also fly long distances.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Water!

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Knife . VOSS passes him the deer-bone knife. With it, he splits the end of his staff, to make a fork out of the end.

Speaker: z oran
Dialogue: What if it's poisonous?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You can still eat it. Just cut off its head. He passes the knife to VOSS, then creeps toward the creature, and striking quickly he attempts to trap the snake in the fork. Too slow. The snake disappears into its hole.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: It's not bad.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Kind of like chicken.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Yeah, a long black poisonous chicken with no legs.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: You know Valka talked of eating each other? In Siberia?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: He did? Would you have eaten me?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Probably.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I would never have eaten you - too stringy and bitter, I'd rather eat snake. VOSS nearly chokes on something, reaches into his mouth, pulls out a tooth.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Scurvy.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: It can kill you, remember? JANUSZ puzzled.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Mister?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: I mightn't know youur first name, but I know your son's name. SMITH stares at him.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Irena told you. JANUSZ nods.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Can I say his name? Nothing from SMITH.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Saying his name on't bring him back. He struggles onto his elbow, staring intently at JANUSZ, an ironic smile on his lips.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Are you giving up?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: In the camps, some saw death as 'freedom'.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: So why didn't you kill yourself?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Survival was a kind of protest. JANUSZ makes him take a little water.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Punishment for what?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I brought David to Russia didn't

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: And no-one can forgive you? And you can't forgive yourself?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Be easier if I had religion, or a home to go back to, like you.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: For us, the old life is gone. They sit in silence for a while.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Irena told me they tortured your wife and she informed on you.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: They did that to my boy.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Tibetan? They move on with renewed energy.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: India? Yes. There is the track to Sikkim, over the mountains. Many people go there.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: And food?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: Small villages there. They give food. Wood for fire. Yes, but you don't go now. CLOSE on JANUSZ, intensely following the conversation.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: Why can't we go now?

Speaker: official
Dialogue: If big snow come - very difficult. You wait here until Spring. This family keep you. He confers with the LAMA.

Speaker: official
Dialogue: He go to Lhasa. Get permission for to stay. Only to Spring. Not possible foreigners stay Tibet. SMITH bows his head, mutters thanks, all of the group doing likewise.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Well, we can't cross in Winter.

Speaker: janusz
Dialogue: He said it was 'difficult'. SMITH comes in, and they make room for him in the cramped space.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I'm going to sleep 'till Spring. Like a bear in a cave. What about you, Mister? SMITH settles with his back to the wall, draws up his sheepskin.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: I'm going to Lhasa. The others are stunned by this.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: 'Looking after number one.' Isn't that what Americans say?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Zoran? ZORAN eventually looks at him.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: He's right. I just realized it.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Realized what?

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Apart from a few mountains, we're there. We made it.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: Not all of us.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: No. Not all of us. Their thoughts drift back to their lost companions.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: 'Home'?

Speaker: z oran
Dialogue: Build metros?

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: Might drift for a while.

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: I will fight. First Germans, then Russians.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: Then re-build your church?

Speaker: voss
Dialogue: I will die fighting. This statement has an oddly prophetic sound. JANUSZ look across at him.

Speaker: zoran
Dialogue: I'm going to get Tomasz's pictures to a newspaper, or get them published somehow. Then I'm going to cook his chicken - but with extra salt just to annoy him. Chuckles from the group.

Speaker: smith
Dialogue: And you, Janusz?
